module.title: name-descriptions
module.p: Name-descriptions are names of specific people, places &c which have been created from a definite common noun phrase.
Name-descriptions can be classified into two distinct grammatical types, based on the kinds of words they are made out of –

ol.li: pre-specified name-descriptions – the common noun is specified by a form of the definite article eg. Am Moireach The Duke of Atholl, Am Ploc Plockton, An Seann-Tiomnadh The Old Testament

post-specified name-descriptions – the common noun is specified by a following genitive word or phrase eg. Fear Chìosmuil MacNeil of Barra, Baile Ùr an t-Slèibhe Newtonmore, Òran na Cloiche [song title]

module.p: Like other names, name-descriptions can also be classified into a number of different semantic types, depending on the kind of entity named –

ol.li: Anthroponymic name-descriptions name people (including personified entities) eg. Am Moireach, Fear Chìosmuil.
Toponymic name-descriptions name places (geographical entities) eg. Am Ploc, Baile Ùr an t-Slèibhe.
Ergonymic name-descriptions name groups, teams, organisations, companies &c eg. An Comunn Gàidhealach The Highland Association, Comhairle nan Leabhraichean The Gaelic Books Council.
Chrematonymic name-descriptions name scholarly and literary texts and other creative works eg. An Seann-Tiomnadh, Òran na Cloiche.
Glottonymic name-descriptions name languages and dialects eg. A’ Ghreugais Greek, Gàidhlig na h-Èireann Irish.
Chrononymic name-descriptions name events and historical eras eg. An Cogadh Mòr The Great War, Linn an Umha The Bronze Age.

module.p: Note that, in pre-specified name-descriptions, the definite article is capitalised in some contexts but not in others, depending on the grammatical/communicative context and the semantic class of the name.

Note also that a few pre-specified name-descriptions are notable in that the nouns involved appear to be more proper than common, in particular names of countries (eg. A’ Ghreug Greece) and languages (eg. A’ Ghreugais Greek). For convenience, we can call these nouns ‘improper’ nouns.
